leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User note:
About this chapter: Chapter 5 establishes the limits to which a building can be built. Building height, number of stories and building area are specified in this chapter. Chapter 5 must be used in conjunction with the occupancies established in Chapter 3 and the types of construction established in Chapter 6. This chapter also specifies the impact that mezzanines, accessory occupancies and mixed occupancies have on the overall size of a building.
leanCodeSectionsTree.displayTitle: Chapter 5 General Building Heights and Areas

children.body: The provisions of this chapter control the height and area of structures hereafter erected and additions to existing structures.

New and existing buildings shall be provided with approved address identification. The address identification shall be legible and placed in a position that is visible from the street or road fronting the property. Address identification characters shall contrast with their background. Address numbers shall be Arabic numbers or alphabetical letters. Numbers shall not be spelled out. Each character shall be a minimum of 4 inches (102 mm) high with a minimum stroke width of 1/2 inch (12.7 mm). Where required by the fire code official, address identification shall be provided in additional approved locations to facilitate emergency response. Where access is by means of a private road and the building address cannot be viewed from the public way, a monument, pole or other approved sign or means shall be used to identify the structure. Address identification shall be maintained.

diagrams.title: Building Address
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Building addresses must be visible from the main road (i.e., the direction of an approaching first responder vehicle). The numbers must be a minimum of 4" tall with each stroke a minimum of 1/2" wide. Numbers are required to be on a background of a contrasting color.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Bldgs w/ Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

children.displayTitle: Section 503 General Building Height and Area Limitations
children.titleText: General Building Height and Area Limitations

children.body: Unless otherwise specifically modified in Chapter 4 and this chapter, building height, number of stories and building area shall not exceed the limits specified in Sections 504 and 506 based on the type of construction as determined by Section 602 and the occupancies as determined by Section 302 except as modified hereafter. Building height, number of stories and building area provisions shall be applied independently. For the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls and Party Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fire Wall: A fire-resistance-rated wall having protected openings, which restricts the spread of fire and extends continuously from the foundation to or through the roof, with sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall.

Use of fire walls separating occupancies where fire separations using fire barriers are required are required to conform to the most restrictive items between the two. Be sure and verify requirements for occupancy separation, incidental use requirements and those related to hazardous materials, among others are met.

diagrams.title: Story Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines Story Above Grade Plane as any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

diagrams.title: Building Height Measurements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Building Height is measured vertically from grade plane to the average height of the highest roof surface. If podium construction or other conditions are used, the provisions of BC Section 510 would apply as applicable. The building code definition of building height is often different from those used in planning / zoning ordinances. In addition, the current definition is different than a previous version in the building code that defined building height for various types of roof structures. Under the current definition, the building height is not measured to the top of the parapet coping.

diagrams.title: Existing Building Additions - Height
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the Existing Building Code, an addition is an extension or increase in floor area, number of stories, or height of a building or structure.

diagrams.title: Single Bldgs. Divided by Fire Walls
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In new construction, for the purposes of determining area limitations, height limitations and type of construction, each portion of a building separated by one or more fire walls complying with Section 706 shall be considered to be a separate building.

Where adopted, the Existing Building Code (IEBC) allows under very certain conditions the use of a fire barrier in lieu of a fire wall when there is a change of occupancy for lower hazard uses. Frequently, it would be very difficult to provide a fully code compliant fire wall in many of these situations.

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

diagrams.title: Occupied Roofs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Occupied roof spaces do not contribute to the building area, number of stories or the building height provided any rooftop structures, present comply with section 1511. The occupancy allowed for an occupied roof must be an occupancy that the code would allow on the floor below the roof deck in accordance with table 504.4. Where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system the occupancy of the occupied roof deck is not limited to occupancies that would be allowed on the story immediately below the roof deck provided an occupant notification system per 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided, and where a voice/alarm communication system per 907.5.2.2 is required elsewhere in the building it is extended to cover the occupied roof. An Assembly occupancy is allowed for occupied roofs over open parking space structures of type I or II construction in accordance with section 903.2.1.6.

Occupancy Exceptions:
  1. The Occupancy shall not be limited to the occupancies allowed on the story immediately below the roof where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system per 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 and occupant notification in per 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided at the occupied roof. Note: Where the building is required to be equipped with a voice/alarm communication system per 907.5.2.2 the occupied roof shall also be covered by the voice/alarm communication system.
  2. Assembly occupancies are permitted on the roof of open parking spaces of type I and II construction per section 903.2.1.6

children.body: Buildings and structures designed to house special industrial processes that require large areas and unusual building heights to accommodate craneways or special machinery and equipment, including, among others, rolling mills; structural metal fabrication shops and foundries; or the production and distribution of electric, gas or steam power, shall be exempt from the building height, number of stories and building area limitations specified in Sections 504 and 506.

Two or more buildings on the same lot shall be regulated as separate buildings or shall be considered as portions of one building where the building height, number of stories of each building and the aggregate building area of the buildings are within the limitations specified in Sections 504 and 506. The provisions of this code applicable to the aggregate building shall be applicable to each building.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot (Ex. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 outlines the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already contains an existing building. To apply this section correctly, an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines is necessary. The designer must establish a fire separation line on the site that aligns with the exterior wall and opening protectives of the existing building. Once this line is defined, the new building can be designed as if this line is a property line. Exception 1 permits the new and existing buildings to be treated as a single structure, thereby eliminating the fire separation protections required by the imaginary fire separation line in the base condition.

Exception 1 limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type present on the site.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. This exception allows for zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage. However, 1-1/2 hour fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with Section 706.8, which limits the size of single openings and the total width of openings relative to the wall length.

children.body: Buildings of Type I construction permitted to be of unlimited tabular building heights and areas are not subject to the special requirements that allow unlimited area buildings in Section 507 or unlimited building height in Sections 503.1.1 and 504.3 or increased building heights and areas for other types of construction.

A roof level or portion thereof shall be permitted to be used as an occupied roof provided the occupancy of the roof is an occupancy that is permitted by Table 504.4 for the story immediately below the roof. The area of the occupied roofs shall not be included in the building area as regulated by Section 506. An occupied roof shall not be included in the building height or number of stories as regulated by Section 504, provided that the penthouses and other enclosed rooftop structures comply with Section 1511.
Exceptions:
  1. The occupancy located on an occupied roof shall not be limited to the occupancies allowed on the story immediately below the roof where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 and occupant notification in accordance with Sections 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided in the area of the occupied roof. Emergency voice/alarm communication system notification per Section 907.5.2.2 shall also be provided in the area of the occupied roof where such system is required elsewhere in the building.
  2. Assembly occupancies shall be permitted on roofs of open parking spaces of Type I or Type II construction, in accordance with the exception to Section 903.2.1.6.

diagrams.title: Occupant Loads: Outdoor Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1004.7 is to ensure that Outdoor Areas have adequate means for emergency evacuation. It gives the building official the authority to determine the occupant load for outdoor areas. It establishes that the Means of Egress for Outdoor Areas be established per the requirements of Chapter 10 of the building code, the same requirements as any other room or space. It provides exceptions for outdoor areas used exclusively for servicing the building and outdoor areas serving R-3 buildings and R-2 dwelling units.

diagrams.title: Egress From Stories or Occupied Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml: For a building to be safe all stories need to be provided with adequate egress. Section 1006.3 requires that each story or occupied roof be provided with the number of separate exits or access to exits based on the occupant load of the story. The number of required exits required for a story are defined in Table 1006.3.3. The exits or exit access from each story need to sized to address the occupant load of the story being served. Section 1005 defines how to size various egress elements. The various stories and occupied roof may share a common exit stairway. An exit stairway serving multiple stories needs to be sized to serve the occupant load of the story or occupied roof with the greatest occupant load that it serves not the aggregate occupant load of all stories served.

diagrams.title: Penthouse Stair Access to Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Penthouse: An enclosed, unoccupied rooftop structure used for sheltering mechanical and electrical equipment, tanks, elevators and related machinery, stairways, and vertical shaft openings.

Penthouses for rooftop access stairs have specific requirements from Chapter 15 as well as Chapter 10.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stair: Occupied Roofs (Ex. 9)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Exit access stairs between different levels of occupied roofs are not requried to be enclosed. Similar to smoke-protected or open-air seating areas, the risk of smoke accumulation is low, reducing the risk.

Remember that the number of stairways, travel distance, separation of stairs and other requirements still must comply with Chapter 10, even though they are not required to be enclosed.

diagrams.title: Rooftop Structures and Penthouses
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Penthouse: An enclosed, unoccupied rooftop structure used for sheltering mechanical and electrical equipment, tanks, elevators and related machinery, and vertical shaft openings.

diagrams.title: Rooftop Vegetated Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A single rooftop garden area can be as large as 15,625 sq.ft. with a maximum dimension of 125'. Each of these areas must be separated by a minimum of 6' wide Class A roofing system and materials. Where the rooftop garden is next to combustible construction, the entire roof area , as well as, areas around service equipment, and other rooftop structures are required to have a minimum 6' wide clear space of Class A roofing materials around them. Roof load requirements for rooftop gardens are outlined in the Section 1607.13.3.1. Class A roofing systems and materials are defined in Section 1505.2.

diagrams.title: Occupied Roofs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Occupied roof spaces do not contribute to the building area, number of stories or the building height provided any rooftop structures, present comply with section 1511. The occupancy allowed for an occupied roof must be an occupancy that the code would allow on the floor below the roof deck in accordance with table 504.4. Where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system the occupancy of the occupied roof deck is not limited to occupancies that would be allowed on the story immediately below the roof deck provided an occupant notification system per 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided, and where a voice/alarm communication system per 907.5.2.2 is required elsewhere in the building it is extended to cover the occupied roof. An Assembly occupancy is allowed for occupied roofs over open parking space structures of type I or II construction in accordance with section 903.2.1.6.

Occupancy Exceptions:
  1. The Occupancy shall not be limited to the occupancies allowed on the story immediately below the roof where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system per 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 and occupant notification in per 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided at the occupied roof. Note: Where the building is required to be equipped with a voice/alarm communication system per 907.5.2.2 the occupied roof shall also be covered by the voice/alarm communication system.
  2. Assembly occupancies are permitted on the roof of open parking spaces of type I and II construction per section 903.2.1.6

children.body:
Elements or structures enclosing the occupied roof areas shall not extend more than 48 inches (1220 mm) above the surface of the occupied roof.
Exception: Penthouses constructed in accordance with Section 1511.2 and towers, domes, spires and cupolas constructed in accordance with Section 1511.5.

diagrams.title: Building Height on Sloping Site
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a site is sloping, the grade plane will likely be at a location different than the story level of the "first floor". So, simply adding the floor to floor heights and the final floor to average roof height may not provide an accurate measurement of the building height.

First, determine the location of grade plane, as a fixed location with a datum (such as elevation above sea level). Then, using the definition of "Story Above Grade Plane", determine if the story in question is either the Story Above Grade Plane, or a basement. The difference between the level of the floor of the Story Above Grade Plane will have to be either added to or subtracted from the building height, measured from the floor of the Story Above Grade Plane to determine an accurate building height measured from grade plane.

Story Above Grade Plane: Any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

diagrams.title: Story Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot (Ex. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 outlines the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already contains an existing building. To apply this section correctly, an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines is necessary. The designer must establish a fire separation line on the site that aligns with the exterior wall and opening protectives of the existing building. Once this line is defined, the new building can be designed as if this line is a property line. Exception 1 permits the new and existing buildings to be treated as a single structure, thereby eliminating the fire separation protections required by the imaginary fire separation line in the base condition.

Exception 1 limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type present on the site.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. This exception allows for zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage. However, 1-1/2 hour fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with Section 706.8, which limits the size of single openings and the total width of openings relative to the wall length.

children.displayTitle: Section 504 Building Height and Number of Stories
children.titleText: Building Height and Number of Stories

children.body:
The height, in feet, and the number of stories of a building shall be determined based on the type of construction, occupancy classification and whether there is an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout the building.
Exception: The building height of one-story aircraft hangars, aircraft paint hangars and buildings used for the manufacturing of aircraft shall not be limited where the building is provided with an automatic sprinkler system or automatic fire-extinguishing system in accordance with Chapter 9 and is entirely surrounded by public ways or yards not less in width than one and one-half times the building height.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Aircraft Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The height of the single story aircraft hangar, or aircraft paint hangar is unlimited if the building is equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler or suppression system.

diagrams.title: Type IIIB Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

Significant exceptions exist in Section 602.3 for buildings of certain occupancies and in fire districts.

diagrams.title: Type IIIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

children.body: The height of unlimited area buildings shall be designed in accordance with Section 507.

diagrams.title: Open Spaces for Unlimited Area Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The proper way to measure required yard space is from the perimeter of the building to the lot line, or face of another building on the same lot. A public way is measured for the entire width of the public way, not just for the portion of the building that fronts the public way.

children.body: The special provisions of Section 510 permit the use of special conditions that are exempt from, or modify, the specific requirements of this chapter regarding the allowable heights of buildings based on the occupancy classification and type of construction, provided the special condition complies with the provisions specified in Section 510.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increase (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Although the provisions of Section 510.5 do not address sprinkler system use, the new (2021) limitations for use of NFPA 13R systems to 4 stories and 30 feet would preclude the use of NFPA 13R for a full height Type III-A building. In addition, non-sprinklered new construction for Group R occupancy is not permitted. Therefore, an NFPA 13 system would be required for this condition.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Horizontal Bldg. Separation (510.2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.2 provides a special condition which would allow a lesser type of construction above a Type I "podium". Sometimes there are multiple buildings over a common podium, which can be common in Group R-2 buildings.

Items that are new for 2018 codes include the allowance for vertical offsets in the horizontal assembly and a requirement for the horizontal assembly to also be Type IA construction.

children.body: In a building containing mixed occupancies in accordance with Section 508, no individual occupancy shall exceed the height and number of story limits specified in this section for the applicable occupancies.

diagrams.title: Allow. Height & Stories: Sep. Occs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The height, in feet, and the number of stories of a building shall be determined based on the type of construction, occupancy classification and whether there is an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout the building. In a building containing mixed occupancies in accordance with Section 508, no individual occupancy shall exceed the height and number of story limits specified in this section for the applicable occupancies.

children.body:
The maximum height, in feet, of a building shall not exceed the limits specified in Table 504.3.
Exception: Towers, spires, steeples and other rooftop structures shall be constructed of materials consistent with the required type of construction of the building except where other construction is permitted by Section 1511.2.4. Such structures shall not be used for habitation or storage. The structures shall be unlimited in height where of noncombustible materials and shall not extend more than 20 feet (6096 mm) above the allowable building height where of combustible materials (see Chapter 15 for additional requirements).

In a building containing mixed occupancies in accordance with Section 508, no individual occupancy shall exceed the height and number of story limits specified in this section for the applicable occupancies.

diagrams.title: Building Height Measurements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Building Height is measured vertically from grade plane to the average height of the highest roof surface. If podium construction or other conditions are used, the provisions of BC Section 510 would apply as applicable. The building code definition of building height is often different from those used in planning / zoning ordinances. In addition, the current definition is different than a previous version in the building code that defined building height for various types of roof structures. Under the current definition, the building height is not measured to the top of the parapet coping.

diagrams.title: Allowable Height Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The allowable building height is measured from grade plane. If the average roof height, measured from grade plane, is less than the height from grade, then the building will comply. In this case, a Type II-B building with an NFPA 13 sprinkler system and with a Group B occupancy is on a sloping site. Since the average roof height is 61 feet above grade plane, and the maximum allowable height is 75 feet, then the building will comply.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Bldgs w/ Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

children.body: The maximum number of stories above grade plane of a building shall not exceed the limits specified in Table 504.4.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increase (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Although the provisions of Section 510.5 do not address sprinkler system use, the new (2021) limitations for use of NFPA 13R systems to 4 stories and 30 feet would preclude the use of NFPA 13R for a full height Type III-A building. In addition, non-sprinklered new construction for Group R occupancy is not permitted. Therefore, an NFPA 13 system would be required for this condition.

diagrams.title: Story Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines Story Above Grade Plane as any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

diagrams.title: Allow. Height & Stories: Sep. Occs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The height, in feet, and the number of stories of a building shall be determined based on the type of construction, occupancy classification and whether there is an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout the building. In a building containing mixed occupancies in accordance with Section 508, no individual occupancy shall exceed the height and number of story limits specified in this section for the applicable occupancies.

diagrams.title: Occupied Roofs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Occupied roof spaces do not contribute to the building area, number of stories or the building height provided any rooftop structures, present comply with section 1511. The occupancy allowed for an occupied roof must be an occupancy that the code would allow on the floor below the roof deck in accordance with table 504.4. Where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system the occupancy of the occupied roof deck is not limited to occupancies that would be allowed on the story immediately below the roof deck provided an occupant notification system per 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided, and where a voice/alarm communication system per 907.5.2.2 is required elsewhere in the building it is extended to cover the occupied roof. An Assembly occupancy is allowed for occupied roofs over open parking space structures of type I or II construction in accordance with section 903.2.1.6.

Occupancy Exceptions:
  1. The Occupancy shall not be limited to the occupancies allowed on the story immediately below the roof where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system per 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 and occupant notification in per 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided at the occupied roof. Note: Where the building is required to be equipped with a voice/alarm communication system per 907.5.2.2 the occupied roof shall also be covered by the voice/alarm communication system.
  2. Assembly occupancies are permitted on the roof of open parking spaces of type I and II construction per section 903.2.1.6

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The room or space that a mezzanine exits through is considered to be a catchment space where the occupant load of both are accumulated before the exiting from the main space is calculated for width and number of exits.

diagrams.title: Structural Member Protection At High Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to Table 601, Footnote b, except in Group F-1, H, M and S-1 occupancies, fire protection of structural members in roof construction shall not be required, including protection of primary structural frame members, roof framing and decking where every part of the roof construction is 20 feet or more above any floor immediately below. Fire-retardant-treated wood members shall be allowed to be used for such unprotected members. However, be aware the 2015 codes does not include the term "primary structural frame members".

UpCodes Note: Primary structural members include columns per the definition. However, per an interpretation on June 22, 2018, regarding the 2018 codes, ICC staff opined that the columns were not part of the fire rating exemption provided by Table 601, footnote b. Per Section 704, if columns are required to be fire rated, the protection is required to extend to its connection with other structural members. Please check with your local AHJ concerning the interpretation of this issue in your locality.

diagrams.title: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Mezzanine: An intermediate level or levels between the floor and ceiling of any story and in accordance with Section 505.

In certain circumstances, mezzanine areas may be increased from one-third of the room below to one-half or two-thirds of the room area below if all requirements of the three exceptions are met. In addition, a number of exceptions exist for allowable enclosure of mezzanines in Section 505.3.

In the 2018 codes, a new exception for dwelling units having NFPA 13 or 13R sprinkler systems was introduced that would allow a mezzanine of up to one-half of the area below.

diagrams.title: Routes: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Advisory 206.2.3 Multi-Story Buildings and Facilities. Spaces and elements located on a level not required to be served by an accessible route must fully comply with this document. While a mezzanine may be a change in level, it is not a story. If an accessible route is required to connect stories within a building or facility, the accessible route must serve all mezzanines.

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

diagrams.title: Equipment Platforms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Equipment platforms by definition have zero occupant load and are elevated platforms that may only be used for mechanical systems equipment or industrial process equipment. Equipment platforms do not contribute to the building area, fire area, or number of stories, and are not considered a portion of the floor below. Elements providing access to the platform such as walkways, stairs, alternating tread devices and ladders may not serve as part of the building's means of egress. Equipment platforms may not be part of a mezzanine.

children.body: Mezzanines shall comply with Section 505.2. Equipment platforms shall comply with Section 505.3.

A mezzanine or mezzanines in compliance with Section 505.2 shall be considered a portion of the story below. Such mezzanines shall not contribute to either the building area or number of stories as regulated by Section 503.1. The area of the mezzanine shall be included in determining the fire area. The clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction shall be not less than 7 feet (2134 mm).

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The room or space that a mezzanine exits through is considered to be a catchment space where the occupant load of both are accumulated before the exiting from the main space is calculated for width and number of exits.

diagrams.title: Mezzanines
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Mezzanine: An intermediate level or levels between the floor and ceiling of any story and in accordance with Section 505.

In certain circumstances, mezzanine areas may be increased from one-third of the room below to one-half or two-thirds of the room area below if all requirements of the three exceptions are met. In addition, a number of exceptions exist for allowable enclosure of mezzanines in Section 505.3.

In the 2018 codes, a new exception for dwelling units having NFPA 13 or 13R sprinkler systems was introduced that would allow a mezzanine of up to one-half of the area below.

diagrams.title: Min. Means of Egress Ceiling Heights
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Provisions for minimum ceiling heights include the minimum allowed heights to ceilings, protrusions, headers and other structural elements and mechanical or plumbing systems including fire sprinklers. The provisions provide allowances in dwelling units for the provision of space for ventilation in corridors (by use of a reduced ceiling height) or the condition where a room walls include the sloping roof, which reduces the ceiling height in a portion of the room. There are exceptions in the existing building code where pre-existing non-conforming ceiling heights may be allowed to remain.

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

children.body:
The aggregate area of a mezzanine or mezzanines within a room shall be not greater than one-third of the floor area of that room or space in which they are located. The enclosed portion of a room shall not be included in a determination of the floor area of the room in which the mezzanine is located. In determining the allowable mezzanine area, the area of the mezzanine shall not be included in the floor area of the room.
Exceptions:
  1. The aggregate area of mezzanines in buildings and structures of Type I or II construction for special industrial occupancies in accordance with Section 503.1.1 shall be not greater than two-thirds of the floor area of the room.
  2. The aggregate area of mezzanines in buildings and structures of Type I or II construction shall be not greater than one-half of the floor area of the room in buildings and structures equipped throughout with an approved automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and an approved emergency voice/alarm communication system in accordance with Section 907.5.2.2.
  3. The aggregate area of a mezzanine within a dwelling unit that is located in a building equipped throughout with an approved automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 shall not be greater than one-half of the floor area of the room, provided that:
    1. Except for enclosed closets and bathrooms, the mezzanine shall be open to the room in which such mezzanine is located;
    2. The opening to the room shall be unobstructed except for walls not more than 42 inches (1067 mm) in height, columns and posts; and
    3. Exceptions to Section 505.2.3 shall not be permitted.

Where a room contains both a mezzanine and an equipment platform, the aggregate area of the two raised floor levels shall be not greater than two-thirds of the floor area of that room or space in which they are located. The area of the mezzanine shall not exceed the area determined in accordance with Section 505.2.1.
children.displayTitle: 505.2.1.1 Aggregate Area of Mezzanines and Equipment Platforms
children.titleText: Aggregate Area of Mezzanines and Equipment Platforms

children.body: The means of egress for mezzanines shall comply with the applicable provisions of Chapter 10.

diagrams.title: Exit Access Stairs: Accessible Means of Egress
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 1009.3.1 is to ensure that all different accessible floor areas and levels within the same story are provided with an accessible means of egress as required by section 1009.1. It does so by eliminating exit access stairways that interconnect different levels on the same story as part of an accessible means of egress. Section 1009.3.1 also provides a special exception for exit access stairways that serve mezzanines to be a part of an accessible means of egress.

children.body:
A mezzanine shall be open and unobstructed to the room in which such mezzanine is located except for walls not more than 42 inches (1067 mm) in height, columns and posts.
Exceptions:
  1. Mezzanines or portions thereof are not required to be open to the room in which the mezzanines are located, provided that the occupant load of the aggregate area of the enclosed space is not greater than 10.
  2. A mezzanine having two or more exits or access to exits is not required to be open to the room in which the mezzanine is located.
  3. Mezzanines or portions thereof are not required to be open to the room in which the mezzanines are located, provided that the aggregate floor area of the enclosed space is not greater than 10 percent of the mezzanine area.
  4. In industrial facilities, mezzanines used for control equipment are permitted to be glazed on all sides.
  5. In occupancies other than Groups H and I, which are no more than two stories above grade plane and equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, a mezzanine having two or more exits or access to exits shall not be required to be open to the room in which the mezzanine is located.

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

children.body: Equipment platforms in buildings shall not be considered as a portion of the floor below. Such equipment platforms shall not contribute to either the building area or the number of stories as regulated by Section 503.1. The area of the equipment platform shall not be included in determining the fire area in accordance with Section 903. Equipment platforms shall not be a part of any mezzanine and such platforms and the walkways, stairways, alternating tread devices and ladders providing access to an equipment platform shall not serve as a part of the means of egress from the building.

diagrams.title: Appliance Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A work space at least 30" wide by 30" deep must be provided immediately in front of the appliance's controls. Access to appliances needs to allow for the appliance to be inspected, operated, serviced and/or replaced without the removal of or disabling the function of any of the following:
  • Fire-resistance rated assembly
  • Permanent Construction such as walls, floors and ceilings
  • Other appliances
  • Venting systems, Ducts or Pipes not connected to the appliance

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

diagrams.title: Mezzanine Area Example - Pt. 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A mezzanine is a portion of a story that is located within a room and is considered a part of the story below. It does not contribute to the building area or the number of stories in the building. Mezzanines must comply with specific regulations outlined in the Building Code, such as the clear height above and below the mezzanine floor construction being not less than 7 feet (Section 505.2). Additionally, the area of the mezzanine is included in determining the fire area (Section 505.2).

diagrams.title: Equipment Platforms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Equipment platforms by definition have zero occupant load and are elevated platforms that may only be used for mechanical systems equipment or industrial process equipment. Equipment platforms do not contribute to the building area, fire area, or number of stories, and are not considered a portion of the floor below. Elements providing access to the platform such as walkways, stairs, alternating tread devices and ladders may not serve as part of the building's means of egress. Equipment platforms may not be part of a mezzanine.

children.body: The aggregate area of all equipment platforms within a room shall be not greater than two-thirds of the area of the room in which they are located. Where an equipment platform is located in the same room as a mezzanine, the area of the mezzanine shall be determined by Section 505.2.1 and the combined aggregate area of the equipment platforms and mezzanines shall be not greater than two-thirds of the room in which they are located. The area of the mezzanine shall not exceed the area determined in accordance with Section 505.2.1.

Where located in a building that is required to be protected by an automatic sprinkler system, equipment platforms shall be fully protected by sprinklers above and below the platform, where required by the standards referenced in Section 903.3.

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Equipment Platforms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Equipment platforms are often found in industrial occupancies and are utilized for mechanical or specific process related equipment. When the building in which these platforms are located is required to have an automatic sprinkler system installed, in accordance with section 903.2, then sprinklers are required to be installed underneath and above the equipment platform. Sprinkler installations are to follow the requirements of the required sprinkler standard (NFPA 13, etc).

children.body: Equipment platforms shall have guards where required by Section 1015.2.

diagrams.title: Guards:  Connection Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
ASCE 7 requires the 200 pound load to be placed in any direction at any point on the handrail or top rail to produce a maximum load effect. This would mean a load pulling on the rail inward would create a maximum tension on the bottom bolt, but a 200 pound force outward (typically associated with "falling" outward) would put the maximum tension on the top bolt.

However, the Residential Code, in Table R301.5, footnote d, states: "A single concentrated load applied in any direction at any point along the top. For a guard not required to serve as a handrail, the load need not be applied to the top element of the guard in a direction parallel to such element." This language does not seem to appear in ASCE 7 at this time.

Therefore, the designer should consider providing tension resisting hardware on both bolts, or consider an alternate design. Simply relying on the rim board would put the member into cross-grain bending, which has considerably lower strength than the beam itself.

diagrams.title: Guards: Where Required
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Wherever there is an open-sided walking area that is more than 30" above the floor level (out to 36" where the ground may slope or be uneven), the walkway requires a guard rail to be in place. There are certain spaces where a guard requirement would not be practical or possible, these areas are exempt from this requirement and include stages and performing areas, truck loading docks, and vehicle servicing pits. Assembly seating areas do not need to comply with this section, but rather, must comply with the guard requirements of Section 1029.17.2. Glass and glazing materials are permitted for use as a guard, however they must meet the performance and strength requirements of sections 2407 and 1607.8 of the building code. Where the glazing does not meet these strength and resistance requirements, guards are required to be installed along with of the glazing.

diagrams.title: Guards: Stairs (Non-Res)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Guardrails at stairs for that are not within a multifamily dwelling unit or for an R-3 residential occupancy have more robust requirements than is required for those that are residential in nature. Verify with the Existing Building Code what requirements must be met when removing / replacing a guardrail, as more current requirements can be more restrictive than when the railing was installed.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot (Ex. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 outlines the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already contains an existing building. To apply this section correctly, an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines is necessary. The designer must establish a fire separation line on the site that aligns with the exterior wall and opening protectives of the existing building. Once this line is defined, the new building can be designed as if this line is a property line. Exception 1 permits the new and existing buildings to be treated as a single structure, thereby eliminating the fire separation protections required by the imaginary fire separation line in the base condition.

Exception 1 limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type present on the site.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. This exception allows for zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage. However, 1-1/2 hour fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with Section 706.8, which limits the size of single openings and the total width of openings relative to the wall length.

diagrams.title: Building Area (Definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the building code, the building area is the area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the building area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.

diagrams.title: Occupied Roofs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Occupied roof spaces do not contribute to the building area, number of stories or the building height provided any rooftop structures, present comply with section 1511. The occupancy allowed for an occupied roof must be an occupancy that the code would allow on the floor below the roof deck in accordance with table 504.4. Where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system the occupancy of the occupied roof deck is not limited to occupancies that would be allowed on the story immediately below the roof deck provided an occupant notification system per 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided, and where a voice/alarm communication system per 907.5.2.2 is required elsewhere in the building it is extended to cover the occupied roof. An Assembly occupancy is allowed for occupied roofs over open parking space structures of type I or II construction in accordance with section 903.2.1.6.

Occupancy Exceptions:
  1. The Occupancy shall not be limited to the occupancies allowed on the story immediately below the roof where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system per 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2 and occupant notification in per 907.5.2.1 and 907.5.2.3 is provided at the occupied roof. Note: Where the building is required to be equipped with a voice/alarm communication system per 907.5.2.2 the occupied roof shall also be covered by the voice/alarm communication system.
  2. Assembly occupancies are permitted on the roof of open parking spaces of type I and II construction per section 903.2.1.6

children.body: The floor area of a building shall be determined based on the type of construction, occupancy classification, whether there is an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout the building and the amount of building frontage on public way or open space.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIIB Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

Significant exceptions exist in Section 602.3 for buildings of certain occupancies and in fire districts.

diagrams.title: Type IIIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

children.body: Unlimited area buildings shall be designed in accordance with Section 507.

The special provisions of Section 510 permit the use of special conditions that are exempt from, or modify, the specific requirements of this chapter regarding the allowable areas of buildings based on the occupancy classification and type of construction, provided the special condition complies with the provisions specified in Section 510.
Basements need not be included in the total allowable floor area of a building provided the total area of such basements does not exceed the area permitted for a one-story above grade plane building.
The allowable area of a building shall be determined in accordance with the applicable provisions of Sections 506.2.1, 506.2.2 and 506.3.

diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

diagrams.title: Buildings on the Same Lot (Ex. 1)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 705.3 outlines the requirements for adding a separate building to a site that already contains an existing building. To apply this section correctly, an understanding of fire separation distances and fire separation lines is necessary. The designer must establish a fire separation line on the site that aligns with the exterior wall and opening protectives of the existing building. Once this line is defined, the new building can be designed as if this line is a property line. Exception 1 permits the new and existing buildings to be treated as a single structure, thereby eliminating the fire separation protections required by the imaginary fire separation line in the base condition.

Exception 1 limits the aggregate height and area to that of the most restrictive occupancy and construction type present on the site.

Exception 2 applies when an S-2 parking garage of Type I or IIA construction is immediately adjacent to an R-2 building. This exception allows for zero fire separation distance between the residences and the garage. However, 1-1/2 hour fire protection is required for openings in the garage wall that abuts the residence. Openings between the two buildings must comply with Section 706.8, which limits the size of single openings and the total width of openings relative to the wall length.

diagrams.title: Nonseparated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Nonseparated occupancies use the most restrictive area per story for the sprinkler system chosen for determining if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the ratio of total building area to allowable area (based on the most restrictive) must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California).

Even though a nonseparated occupancy may meet the area and height requirements, occupancy separations are required in certain situations such as H or R occupancies regardless. Also, the required floor/ceiling and structural ratings must also be met for the type of construction chosen.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

diagrams.title: Nonseparated Occupancies 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Nonseparated occupancies use the most restrictive area per story for the sprinkler system chosen for determining if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the ratio of total building area to allowable area (based on the most restrictive) must be less than 3 (or 2, for two stories and certain occupancy groups in California).

Even though a nonseparated occupancy may meet the area and height requirements, occupancy separations are required in certain situations such as H or R occupancies regardless. Also, the required floor/ceiling and structural ratings must also be met for the type of construction chosen.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

diagrams.title: Separated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Separated occupancies check the sum of the ratios of designed-to-allowable areas for each story to determine if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the sum of the ratios of each story must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California). If additional area is needed, the frontage factor based on frontage can be used to increase the values beyond the allowable area values.

Occupancy separations are required to be Fire Barriers in accordance with Table 508.4.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

children.body:
The allowable area of each story of a single-occupancy building shall be determined in accordance with Equation 5-1:

Aa = Allowable area (square feet).
At = Tabular allowable area factor (NS, S1, S13R or S13D value, as applicable) in accordance with Table 506.2.
NS = Tabular allowable area factor in accordance with Table 506.2 for nonsprinklered building (regardless of whether the building is sprinklered).
If = Area factor increase due to frontage (percent) as calculated in accordance with Section 506.3.
The allowable area per story of a single-occupancy building with a maximum of three stories above grade shall be determined by Equation 5-1. The total allowable area of a single-occupancy building more than three stories above grade plane shall be determined in accordance with Equation 5-2:

(Equation 5-2)
where:
Aa = Allowable area (square feet).
At = Tabular allowable area factor (NS, S13R, S13D or SM value, as applicable) in accordance with Table 506.2.
NS = Tabular allowable area factor in accordance with Table 506.2 for a nonsprinklered building (regardless of whether the building is sprinklered).
If = Area factor increase due to frontage (percent) as calculated in accordance with Section 506.3.
Sa = 3 where the actual number of stories above grade plane exceeds three, or
Sa = 4 where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.2.
The actual area of any individual floor shall not exceed the allowable area per Equation 5-1.

diagrams.title: Story Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines Story Above Grade Plane as any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

children.body:
The allowable area of each story of a mixed-occupancy building shall be determined in accordance with the applicable provisions of, Section 508.3.2 for nonseparated occupancies and Section 508.4.2 for separated occupancies.
For buildings with more than three stories above grade plane, the total building area shall be such that the aggregate sum of the ratios of the actual area of each story divided by the allowable area of such stories, determined in accordance with Equation 5-3 based on the applicable provisions of Section 508.1, shall not exceed three.
(Equation 5-3)
Aa = Allowable area (square feet).
At = Tabular allowable area factor (NS, S13R, S13D or SM value, as applicable) in accordance with Table 506.2.
NS = Tabular allowable area factor in accordance with Table 506.2 for a nonsprinklered building, regardless of whether the building is sprinklered.
If = Area factor increase due to frontage (percent) as calculated in accordance with Section 506.3.
Exception: For buildings designed as separated occupancies under Section 508.4 and equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.2, the total building area shall be such that the aggregate sum of the ratios of the actual area of each story divided by the allowable area of such stories determined in accordance with Equation 5-3 based on the applicable provisions of Section 508.1, shall not exceed four.

diagrams.title: Story Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines Story Above Grade Plane as any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

diagrams.title: Nonseparated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Nonseparated occupancies use the most restrictive area per story for the sprinkler system chosen for determining if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the ratio of total building area to allowable area (based on the most restrictive) must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California).

Even though a nonseparated occupancy may meet the area and height requirements, occupancy separations are required in certain situations such as H or R occupancies regardless. Also, the required floor/ceiling and structural ratings must also be met for the type of construction chosen.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

diagrams.title: Nonseparated Occupancies 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Nonseparated occupancies use the most restrictive area per story for the sprinkler system chosen for determining if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the ratio of total building area to allowable area (based on the most restrictive) must be less than 3 (or 2, for two stories and certain occupancy groups in California).

Even though a nonseparated occupancy may meet the area and height requirements, occupancy separations are required in certain situations such as H or R occupancies regardless. Also, the required floor/ceiling and structural ratings must also be met for the type of construction chosen.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

diagrams.title: Separated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Separated occupancies check the sum of the ratios of designed-to-allowable areas for each story to determine if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the sum of the ratios of each story must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California). If additional area is needed, the frontage factor based on frontage can be used to increase the values beyond the allowable area values.

Occupancy separations are required to be Fire Barriers in accordance with Table 508.4.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

children.body: For a building containing Group H-2 or H-3 occupancies, the allowable area shall be determined in accordance with Section 508.4.2, with the automatic sprinkler system increase applicable only to the portions of the building not classified as Group H-2 or H-3.
children.displayTitle: 506.2.2.1 Group H-2 or H-3 Mixed Occupancies
children.titleText: Group H-2 or H-3 Mixed Occupancies

children.body: Every building shall adjoin or have access to a public way to receive an area factor increase based on frontage. Area factor increase shall be determined in accordance with Sections 506.3.1 through 506.3.3.

diagrams.title: Area Factor Increase for Frontage (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The distances used to measure the open space are different than the distances for fire-separation distance. Open spaces are measured to the closest interior lot line, the entire width of a street, alley or public way, or to the exterior face of an adjacent building on the same property. The frontage increase shall be based on the smallest public way or open space that is 20 feet or greater, and the percentage of building perimeter having a minimum 20 feet public way or open space.

Previously, this was calculated by a formula, but in this code edition, it is a tabulated value. The tabulated values are permitted to be interprolated.

children.body: To qualify for an area factor increase based on frontage, a building shall have not less than 25 percent of its perimeter on a public way or open space. Such open space shall be either on the same lot or dedicated for public use and shall be accessed from a street or approved fire lane.

To qualify for an area factor increase based on frontage, the public way or open space adjacent to the building perimeter shall have a minimum distance (W) of 20 feet (6096 mm) measured at right angles from the building face to any of the following:
  1. The closest interior lot line.
  2. The entire width of a street, alley or public way.
  3. The exterior face of an adjacent building on the same property.
The frontage increase shall be based on the smallest public way or open space that is 20 feet (6096 mm) or greater, and the percentage of building perimeter having a minimum 20 feet (6096 mm) public way or open space.
The area factor increase based on frontage shall be determined in accordance with Table 506.3.3.

diagrams.title: Area Factor Increase for Frontage (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The distances used to measure the open space are different than the distances for fire-separation distance. Open spaces are measured to the closest interior lot line, the entire width of a street, alley or public way, or to the exterior face of an adjacent building on the same property. The frontage increase shall be based on the smallest public way or open space that is 20 feet or greater, and the percentage of building perimeter having a minimum 20 feet public way or open space.

Previously, this was calculated by a formula, but in this code edition, it is a tabulated value. The tabulated values are permitted to be interprolated.

children.body: Where a building meets the requirements of Section 507, as applicable, except for compliance with the minimum 60-foot (18 288 mm) public way or yard requirement, the area factor increase based on frontage shall be determined in accordance with Table 506.3.3.1.

diagrams.title: Open Spaces for Unlimited Area Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The proper way to measure required yard space is from the perimeter of the building to the lot line, or face of another building on the same lot. A public way is measured for the entire width of the public way, not just for the portion of the building that fronts the public way.

diagrams.title: Yards and Courts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines yards and courts as:

Yard: An open space, other than a court, unobstructed from the ground to the sky, except where specifically provided by this code, on the lot on which a building is situated.

Court:An open, uncovered space, unobstructed to the sky, bounded on three or more sides by exterior building walls or other enclosing devices.

diagrams.title: Open Spaces for Unlimited Area Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The proper way to measure required yard space is from the perimeter of the building to the lot line, or face of another building on the same lot. A public way is measured for the entire width of the public way, not just for the portion of the building that fronts the public way.
