diagrams.title: Unlimited Bldg Area: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occs.
Unlimited Area Buildings: Reduced Open Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 507.2.1 allows the required 60 ft wide public ways or yards around unlimited area buildings to be reduced to a minimum of 40 ft, as long as three conditions are met: the reduced width can't exceed 75% of the building's perimeter, the exterior walls facing the reduced width area must have at least a 3 hour fire-resistance rating, and any openings in those walls must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.

children.body: The area of buildings of the occupancies and configurations specified in Sections 507.1 through 507.13 shall not be limited. Basements not more than one story below grade plane shall be permitted.

Accessory occupancies shall be permitted in unlimited area buildings in accordance with the provisions of Section 508.2, otherwise the requirements of Sections 507.3 through 507.13 shall be applied, where applicable.

diagrams.title: Accessory Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The use of accessory occupancies is one of three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements

children.body:
Where Sections 507.3 through 507.13 require buildings to be surrounded and adjoined by public ways and yards, those open spaces shall be determined as follows:
  1. Yards shall be measured from the building perimeter in all directions to the closest interior lot lines or to the exterior face of an opposing building located on the same lot, as applicable.
  2. Where the building fronts on a public way, the entire width of the public way shall be used.

diagrams.title: Open Spaces for Unlimited Area Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The proper way to measure required yard space is from the perimeter of the building to the lot line, or face of another building on the same lot. A public way is measured for the entire width of the public way, not just for the portion of the building that fronts the public way.

children.body:
The public ways or yards of 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width required in Sections 507.3, 507.4, 507.5, 507.6 and 507.12 shall be permitted to be reduced to not less than 40 feet (12 192 mm) in width, provided that the following requirements are met:
  1. The reduced width shall not be allowed for more than 75 percent of the perimeter of the building.
  2. The exterior walls facing the reduced width shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.
  3. Openings in the exterior walls facing the reduced width shall have opening protectives with a fire protection rating of not less than 3 hours.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Buildings: Reduced Open Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 507.2.1 allows the required 60 ft wide public ways or yards around unlimited area buildings to be reduced to a minimum of 40 ft, as long as three conditions are met: the reduced width can't exceed 75% of the building's perimeter, the exterior walls facing the reduced width area must have at least a 3 hour fire-resistance rating, and any openings in those walls must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.

children.body: The area of a Group F-2 or S-2 building not more than one story in height shall not be limited where the building is surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less than 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Buildings: Reduced Open Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 507.2.1 allows the required 60 ft wide public ways or yards around unlimited area buildings to be reduced to a minimum of 40 ft, as long as three conditions are met: the reduced width can't exceed 75% of the building's perimeter, the exterior walls facing the reduced width area must have at least a 3 hour fire-resistance rating, and any openings in those walls must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.

children.body:
The area of a Group A-4 building not more than one story above grade plane of other than Type V construction, or the area of a Group B, F, M or S building no more than one story above grade plane of any construction type, shall not be limited where the building is provided with an automatic sprinkler system throughout in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and is surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less than 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width.
Exceptions:
  1. Buildings and structures of Type I or II construction for rack storage facilities that do not have access by the public shall not be limited in height, provided that such buildings conform to the requirements of Sections 507.4 and 903.3.1.1 and Chapter 32 of the International Fire Code.
  2. The automatic sprinkler system shall not be required in areas occupied for indoor participant sports, such as tennis, skating, swimming and equestrian activities in occupancies in Group A-4, provided that the following criteria are met:
    1. Exit doors directly to the outside are provided for occupants of the participant sports areas.
    2. The building is equipped with a fire alarm system with manual fire alarm boxes installed in accordance with Section 907.
    3. An automatic sprinkler system is provided in storage rooms, press boxes, concession booths or other spaces ancillary to the sport activity space.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Buildings: Reduced Open Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 507.2.1 allows the required 60 ft wide public ways or yards around unlimited area buildings to be reduced to a minimum of 40 ft, as long as three conditions are met: the reduced width can't exceed 75% of the building's perimeter, the exterior walls facing the reduced width area must have at least a 3 hour fire-resistance rating, and any openings in those walls must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.

children.body:
Group A-1 and A-2 occupancies of other than Type V construction shall be permitted within mixed occupancy buildings of unlimited area complying with Section 507.4, provided that the following criteria are met:
  1. Group A-1 and A-2 occupancies are separated from other occupancies as required for separated occupancies in Section 508.4.4 with no reduction allowed in the fire-resistance rating of the separation based upon the installation of an automatic sprinkler system.
  2. Each area of the portions of the building used for Group A-1 or A-2 occupancies shall not exceed the maximum allowable area permitted for such occupancies in Section 503.1.
  3. Exit doors from Group A-1 and A-2 occupancies shall discharge directly to the exterior of the building.
children.displayTitle: 507.4.1 Mixed Occupancy Buildings With Groups A-1 and A-2
children.titleText: Mixed Occupancy Buildings With Groups A-1 and A-2

children.body: The area of a Group B, F, M or S building not more than two stories above grade plane shall not be limited where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and is surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less than 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Buildings: Reduced Open Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 507.2.1 allows the required 60 ft wide public ways or yards around unlimited area buildings to be reduced to a minimum of 40 ft, as long as three conditions are met: the reduced width can't exceed 75% of the building's perimeter, the exterior walls facing the reduced width area must have at least a 3 hour fire-resistance rating, and any openings in those walls must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.

children.body:
The area of a Group A-3 building not more than one story above grade plane, used as a place of religious worship, community hall, dance hall, exhibition hall, gymnasium, lecture hall, indoor swimming pool or tennis court of Type II construction, shall not be limited provided that the following criteria are met:
  1. The building shall not have a stage other than a platform.
  2. The building shall be equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  3. The building shall be surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less than 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Buildings: Reduced Open Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 507.2.1 allows the required 60 ft wide public ways or yards around unlimited area buildings to be reduced to a minimum of 40 ft, as long as three conditions are met: the reduced width can't exceed 75% of the building's perimeter, the exterior walls facing the reduced width area must have at least a 3 hour fire-resistance rating, and any openings in those walls must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.

children.displayTitle: 507.6 Group A-3 Buildings of Type II Construction
children.titleText: Group A-3 Buildings of Type II Construction

children.body:
The area of a Group A-3 building of Type III or IV construction, with not more than one story above grade plane and used as a place of religious worship, community hall, dance hall, exhibition hall, gymnasium, lecture hall, indoor swimming pool or tennis court, shall not be limited provided that the following criteria are met:
  1. The building shall not have a stage other than a platform.
  2. The building shall be equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  3. The assembly floor shall be located at or within 21 inches (533 mm) of street or grade level and all exits are provided with ramps complying with Section 1012 to the street or grade level.
  4. The building shall be surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less than 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width.
children.displayTitle: 507.7 Group A-3 Buildings of Type III and IV Construction
children.titleText: Group A-3 Buildings of Type III and IV Construction

children.body: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 occupancies shall be permitted in unlimited area buildings containing Group F or S occupancies in accordance with Sections 507.4 and 507.5 and the provisions of Sections 507.8.1 through 507.8.4.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Exception: Group H
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Rooms classified in the Occupancy Groups of H-2 and H-3 contain hazardous materials presenting concern for deflagration, accelerated burning, increased rate of combustion, or other physical hazards. In order to minimize impact of a fire event to the building, and improve suppression/rescue personnel access to these occupancies, the code requires 25% of the occupancy perimeter walls/barriers to be located on the exterior wall. The code allows exceptions to the 25% requirement for the following conditions:
  1. Liquid storage rooms up to 1,000 sf that meet all applicable provisions of the Fire Code and NFPA 30.
  2. Liquid use, dispensing and mixing rooms up to 500 sf that meet all applicable provisions of the Fire Code and NFPA 30.
  3. Paint Spray Booths that meet all applicable provisions of the Fire Code.

It is important to note that the Liquid Storage Room, the Dispensing/Mixing Room and the Paint Spray Booth each have separate requirements specified by both the building and fire codes (e.g. size, construction, location, spill control, secondary containment, operational controls, etc.). In order to qualify for one of the three exceptions the area under consideration must meet all building and fire code requirements for the area.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Bldg Area: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occs.

children.displayTitle: 507.8 Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occupancies
children.titleText: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occupancies

children.body: The aggregate floor area of Group H occupancies located in an unlimited area building shall not exceed 10 percent of the area of the building or the area limitations for the Group H occupancies as specified in Section 506 based on the perimeter of each Group H floor area that fronts on a public way or open space.

The aggregate floor area of Group H occupancies not located at the perimeter of the building shall not exceed 25 percent of the area limitations for the Group H occupancies as specified in Section 506.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Bldg Area: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occs.

children.body: Rooms for flammable or combustible liquid use, dispensing or mixing in open systems having a floor area of not more than 500 square feet (46.5 m2) need not be located on the outer perimeter of the building where they are in accordance with the International Fire Code and NFPA 30.
children.displayTitle: 507.8.1.1.1 Rooms for Flammable or Combustible Liquid Use, Dispensing or Mixing in Open Systems
children.titleText: Rooms for Flammable or Combustible Liquid Use, Dispensing or Mixing in Open Systems

children.body: Liquid storage rooms and rooms for flammable or combustible liquid use in closed systems having a floor area of not more than 1,000 square feet (93 m2) need not be located on the outer perimeter where they are in accordance with the International Fire Code and NFPA 30.
children.displayTitle: 507.8.1.1.2 Liquid Storage Rooms and Rooms for Flammable or Combustible Liquid Use in Closed Systems
children.titleText: Liquid Storage Rooms and Rooms for Flammable or Combustible Liquid Use in Closed Systems

children.body: Spray paint booths that comply with the International Fire Code need not be located on the outer perimeter.

Except as provided for in Section 507.8.1.1, Group H occupancies shall be located on the perimeter of the building. In Group H-2 and H-3 occupancies, not less than 25 percent of the perimeter of such occupancies shall be an exterior wall.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Bldg Area: Group H-2, H-3 and H-4 Occs.

children.body: Group H occupancies shall be separated from the remainder of the unlimited area building and from each other in accordance with Table 508.4.

For two-story, unlimited area buildings, Group H occupancies shall not be located more than one story above grade plane unless permitted based on the allowable height and number of stories and feet as specified in Section 504 based on the type of construction of the unlimited area building.

The area of a Group B, F, H-5, M or S building not more than two stories above grade plane shall not be limited where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, and is surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less than 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width, provided that the following criteria are met:
  1. Buildings containing Group H-5 occupancy shall be of Type I or II construction.
  2. Each area used for Group H-5 occupancy shall be separated from other occupancies as required in Sections 415.11 and 508.4.
  3. Each area used for Group H-5 occupancy shall not exceed the maximum allowable area permitted for such occupancies in Section 503.1 including modifications of Section 506.
    Exception: Where the Group H-5 occupancy exceeds the maximum allowable area, the Group H-5 shall be subdivided into areas that are separated by 2-hour fire barriers.
children.displayTitle: 507.9 Unlimited Mixed Occupancy Buildings With Group H-5
children.titleText: Unlimited Mixed Occupancy Buildings With Group H-5

children.body: The area of a Group H-2 aircraft paint hangar not more than one story above grade plane shall not be limited where such aircraft paint hangar complies with the provisions of Section 412.5 and is surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less in width than one and one-half times the building height.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Aircraft Bldgs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The height of the single story aircraft hangar, or aircraft paint hangar is unlimited if the building is equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler or suppression system.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Paint Hangers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Aircraft paint hangars can be unlimited in area if they are classified as a Group H-2, are no more than one story above grade, and meet all the requirements of Section 412.5.

children.body:
The area of a Group E building not more than one story above grade plane, of Type II, IIIA or IV construction, shall not be limited provided that the following criteria are met:
  1. Each classroom shall have not less than two means of egress, with one of the means of egress being a direct exit to the outside of the building complying with Section 1022.
  2. The building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  3. The building is surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less than 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width.

In buildings of Type II construction, the area of a motion picture theater located on the first story above grade plane shall not be limited where the building is provided with an automatic sprinkler system throughout in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and is surrounded and adjoined by public ways or yards not less than 60 feet (18 288 mm) in width.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Buildings: Reduced Open Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Section 507.2.1 allows the required 60 ft wide public ways or yards around unlimited area buildings to be reduced to a minimum of 40 ft, as long as three conditions are met: the reduced width can't exceed 75% of the building's perimeter, the exterior walls facing the reduced width area must have at least a 3 hour fire-resistance rating, and any openings in those walls must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.

children.body: The area of covered and open mall buildings and anchor buildings not exceeding three stories in height that comply with Section 402 shall not be limited.
children.displayTitle: 507.13 Covered and Open Mall Buildings and Anchor Buildings
children.titleText: Covered and Open Mall Buildings and Anchor Buildings

diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

diagrams.title: Accessory Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The use of accessory occupancies is one of three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

diagrams.title: Live Work Unit Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Live/work units regulated under 2021-based building code Section 508.5 present a highly adaptable occupancy model, particularly well-suited to dense urban environments and multifamily developments. However, this hybrid typology comes with precise constraints that significantly influence spatial planning.

Means of egress and accessibility requrements apply based on the function of each space. Occupant loads must be calculated and documented separately for the living and working portions. Plumbing fixture count calculations also require careful attention, particularly in jurisdictions with stricter interpretations of how shared facilities may be used. If a tenant brings in external workers or clients—even occasionally—it may shift the classification of the work zone in ways that trigger more demanding requirements for fixtures, structural design, or fire protection. Uses such as light fabrication, artist studios, or boutique production can blur the line between permitted commercial activities and those prohibited under Group H or S occupancies, such as those involving hazardous materials or heavy storage. It is essential to engage the Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ) early to determine how they define and enforce these distinctions in mixed-use contexts.

Egress requirements must be carefully considered before simply choosing something like a spiral stair or residential style stairway. Ventilation requirements under the Mechanical Code must be applied according to the function of each space, which could complicate HVAC zoning and system layouts. Similarly, fire alarm and sprinkler designs must account for both residential and commercial activities within a single unit envelope. These complexities demand a multidisciplinary approach to design coordination—where architecture, mechanical systems, code compliance, and occupancy planning are considered together from the earliest project stages.

children.body:
Each portion of a building shall be individually classified in accordance with Section 302.1. Where a building contains more than one occupancy group, the building or portion thereof shall comply with the applicable provisions of Section 508.2, 508.3, 508.4 or 508.5, or a combination of these sections.
Exceptions:
  1. Occupancies separated in accordance with Section 510.
  2. Where required by Table 415.6.5, areas of Group H-1, H-2 and H-3 occupancies shall be located in a detached building or structure.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Horizontal Bldg. Separation (510.2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.2 provides a special condition which would allow a lesser type of construction above a Type I "podium". Sometimes there are multiple buildings over a common podium, which can be common in Group R-2 buildings.

Items that are new for 2018 codes include the allowance for vertical offsets in the horizontal assembly and a requirement for the horizontal assembly to also be Type IA construction.

children.body: Accessory occupancies are those occupancies that are ancillary to the main occupancy of the building or portion thereof. Accessory occupancies shall comply with the provisions of Sections 508.2.1 through 508.2.4.

diagrams.title: Cumulative Occ. Loads: Intervening Spaces/Accessory Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Cumulative occupant loads affect egress design when occupants must pass through shared or intervening spaces en route to an exit. When multiple rooms discharge through a common space, that space must be designed to accommodate the total number of occupants that pass through it—not just its own occupant load.

This approach ensures the egress system is appropriately sized for actual use conditions. However, it's important to understand that this requirement applies only to the occupants who traverse the shared path. If a space has multiple exit routes and some occupants do not use the intervening area, only those who do contribute to the cumulative load at that point. This avoids artificially inflating the required egress capacity by counting occupants twice.

Architects should take care during the early planning stages to analyze not just the occupant load of rooms, but also the actual flow of occupants during egress, tracing how people move through space and identifying bottlenecks. It's especially important in open or hybrid layouts—such as coworking areas, medical offices, or tenant spaces within larger occupancies—where paths of travel may be shared or split. Misinterpreting who contributes to the cumulative load can lead to over- or under-designing critical egress components, affecting code compliance and occupant safety.

diagrams.title: Accessory Occupancies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The use of accessory occupancies is one of three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Accessory Occ.: Example
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Accessory occupancies are part of the mixed occupancy provisions to allow small amounts of spaces that are used by other parts of the same space but not count against them in regards to allowable area calculations. They may be used in combination with separated and non-separated occupancy provisions. For example, an office in a retail establishment, or a small conference room in a large office space.

The two spaces on the left, because they support (and have some sort of spacial connection to the main space), are ancillary; therefore, they can be "Accessory occupancies". Tenant space #2 is separate, does not support the tenant #1 space, nor is it connected. Therefore, it is not ancillary and cannot likely be an accessory occupancy. If a space supports a main space, but is not directly connected, the design professional should make a determination if this is an appropriate accessory occupancy designation.

children.body: Accessory occupancies shall be individually classified in accordance with Section 302.1. The requirements of this code shall apply to each portion of the building based on the occupancy classification of that space.

diagrams.title: Edu. Accessory to Group A
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces that are accessory to and exclusively support the primary E Occupancy are not required to be classified as Assembly occupancy, even if the occupant load exceeds 50. Such spaces still must meet egress requirements of an A occupancy, such as door swing panic hardware, exit signs, emergency lighting, etc. However they would be evaluated concurrent with the E Occupancy for building construction, height/area and fire protection system requirements. Spaces such as multi-purpose rooms, cafeterias and gymnasiums commonly qualify for the exemption. However, it is important to note that if the space is used for purposes other than the primary E Occupancy, such as public gatherings or other community use, it should be classified as A Occupancy, and meet all requirements as such.

children.body: The allowable height and number of stories of the building containing accessory occupancies shall be in accordance with Section 504 for the main occupancy of the building.

diagrams.title: Building Height Measurements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Building Height is measured vertically from grade plane to the average height of the highest roof surface. If podium construction or other conditions are used, the provisions of BC Section 510 would apply as applicable. The building code definition of building height is often different from those used in planning / zoning ordinances. In addition, the current definition is different than a previous version in the building code that defined building height for various types of roof structures. Under the current definition, the building height is not measured to the top of the parapet coping.

children.body: The allowable area of the building shall be based on the applicable provisions of Section 506 for the main occupancy of the building. Aggregate accessory occupancies shall not occupy more than 10 percent of the floor area of the story in which they are located and shall not exceed the tabular values for nonsprinklered buildings in Table 506.2 for each such accessory occupancy.

No separation is required between accessory occupancies and the main occupancy.
Exceptions:
  1. Group H-2, H-3, H-4 and H-5 occupancies shall be separated from all other occupancies in accordance with Section 508.4.
  2. Group I-1, R-1, R-2 and R-3 dwelling units and sleeping units shall be separated from other dwelling or sleeping units and from accessory occupancies contiguous to them in accordance with the requirements of Section 420.
Buildings or portions of buildings that comply with the provisions of this section shall be considered as nonseparated occupancies.

diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

children.body: Nonseparated occupancies shall be individually classified in accordance with Section 302.1. The requirements of this code shall apply to each portion of the building based on the occupancy classification of that space. In addition, the most restrictive provisions of Chapter 9 that apply to the nonseparated occupancies shall apply to the total nonseparated occupancy area.

diagrams.title: Fire Areas: Multi. Occ., Non-Rated vs. Rated Separation
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
For non-separated occupancies, Section 508.3.1 states the most restrictive provision of Chapter 9 shall apply to the entire area. Therefore, even though there are no limits to B Occupancy fire areas, when combined with an F-1 Occupancy, for example, the 12,000 sq. ft. limit would apply to the total area of F-1 and B.

UpCodes Note: This is a separate concept from separated occupancies found in Section 508. However fire barriers used for fire area separation may also be used as occupancy separations found in Section 508 if both fire rating requirements are met.

children.body: Where nonseparated occupancies occur in a high-rise building, the most restrictive requirements of Section 403 that apply to the nonseparated occupancies shall apply throughout the high-rise building.

Where one of the nonseparated occupancies is Group I-2, Condition 2, the most restrictive requirements of Sections 407, 509 and 712 shall apply throughout the fire area containing the Group I-2 occupancy. The most restrictive requirements of Chapter 10 shall apply to the path of egress from the Group I-2, Condition 2 occupancy up to and including the exit discharge.

The allowable building area, height and number of stories of the building or portion thereof shall be based on the most restrictive allowances for the occupancy groups under consideration for the type of construction of the building in accordance with Section 503.1.

diagrams.title: Building Height on Sloping Site
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a site is sloping, the grade plane will likely be at a location different than the story level of the "first floor". So, simply adding the floor to floor heights and the final floor to average roof height may not provide an accurate measurement of the building height.

First, determine the location of grade plane, as a fixed location with a datum (such as elevation above sea level). Then, using the definition of "Story Above Grade Plane", determine if the story in question is either the Story Above Grade Plane, or a basement. The difference between the level of the floor of the Story Above Grade Plane will have to be either added to or subtracted from the building height, measured from the floor of the Story Above Grade Plane to determine an accurate building height measured from grade plane.

Story Above Grade Plane: Any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

diagrams.title: Nonseparated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Nonseparated occupancies use the most restrictive area per story for the sprinkler system chosen for determining if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the ratio of total building area to allowable area (based on the most restrictive) must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California).

Even though a nonseparated occupancy may meet the area and height requirements, occupancy separations are required in certain situations such as H or R occupancies regardless. Also, the required floor/ceiling and structural ratings must also be met for the type of construction chosen.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

diagrams.title: Nonseparated Occupancies 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Nonseparated occupancies use the most restrictive area per story for the sprinkler system chosen for determining if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the ratio of total building area to allowable area (based on the most restrictive) must be less than 3 (or 2, for two stories and certain occupancy groups in California).

Even though a nonseparated occupancy may meet the area and height requirements, occupancy separations are required in certain situations such as H or R occupancies regardless. Also, the required floor/ceiling and structural ratings must also be met for the type of construction chosen.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

children.displayTitle: 508.3.2 Allowable Building Area, Height and Number of Stories
children.titleText: Allowable Building Area, Height and Number of Stories

children.body:
No separation is required between nonseparated occupancies.
Exceptions:
  1. Group H-2, H-3, H-4 and H-5 occupancies shall be separated from all other occupancies in accordance with Section 508.4.
  2. Group I-1, R-1, R-2 and R-3 dwelling units and sleeping units shall be separated from other dwelling or sleeping units and from other occupancies contiguous to them in accordance with the requirements of Section 420.
Buildings or portions of buildings that comply with the provisions of this section shall be considered as separated occupancies.

diagrams.title: Fire Rated Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire rated wall assemblies are of three varieties: fire walls, fire barriers and fire partitions. Fire barriers can be used as shaft enclosures, occupancy separations and others. Fire partitions are often used as demising walls and corridor separations, among other uses.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Non Separated vs. Separated Occ.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The use of separated and non-separated occupancies is two of the three methods prescribed by the code to account for multiple occupancy buildings. It may be used in combination with the others.

Non-separated occupancies offer more open planning options and reduced wall construction, but come at the cost of treating the entire building (or portion thereof) as the most restrictive occupancy group. This affects not only allowable area and height, but also fire protection features—especially under Chapter 9, where sprinkler requirements, fire alarms, and smoke control systems must meet the higher standard across the board. From an implementation standpoint, non-separated occupancies are simpler to document but more limiting for maximizing usable area, particularly when integrating high-intensity uses like Assembly (Group A-3) with lower-risk uses like Business (Group B).

Separated occupancies require rated fire barriers and/or rated horizontal assemblies between different occupancy groups per Section 508.4. In addition the structural systems supporting these barriers must also themselves be rated. This introduces complexity in detailing, cost, and coordination across MEP penetrations and egress paths. However, this separation allows each occupancy to retain its own allowable area, height, and fire protection approach, often resulting in better yield for multi-use buildings.

Non-separation of occupancy groups does not eliminate the need for fire ratings related to specific features, such as corridors, control areas, shafts, an atrium, two-story openings, etc. In these situations, the specific code requirements for separations must be used even if the overall building is considered non-separated, as the separation is a condition of the specific feature, such as an atrium or opening between levels (See Section 712.1.9).

Similarly, "separation" is only recognized where a rated assembly is continuous and properly detailed—meaning partial separations, stub walls, or incomplete barriers do not count toward code compliance. Architects must engage early with code consultants and AHJs to align expectations, especially when pursuing performance-based design or leveraging exceptions (e.g., Section 510 for podium construction or control areas for hazardous materials) that can further complicate occupancy separations.

diagrams.title: Allow. Height & Stories: Sep. Occs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The height, in feet, and the number of stories of a building shall be determined based on the type of construction, occupancy classification and whether there is an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout the building. In a building containing mixed occupancies in accordance with Section 508, no individual occupancy shall exceed the height and number of story limits specified in this section for the applicable occupancies.

diagrams.title: Private Garage Separation from Dwelling Units (BC)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Because the garage is a motor vehicle related occupancy there are special requirements in the code. Section 406.3.2 specifically addresses the fire separation and protection requirements for a private garage that is constructed directly adjacent to or as part of a dwelling unit. The garage is required to be separated from the dwelling unit and its attic area by means of gypsum board, not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in thickness, applied to the garage side. If there is a habitable room located above the garage, then a 5/8-inch Type X gypsum board or equivalent and 1/2-inch gypsum board separation is required on the garage side where the condition exists. Structural elements in the garage supporting the habitable spaces will also require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation.

Example: A post or a wall in the garage that supports a habitable floor above the garage space will require 1/2-inch gypsum board separation. The code then goes on to define door opening requirements for openings between a private garage and a dwelling unit. The leaf itself shall be constructed of either solid wood doors or solid or honeycomb core steel doors not less than 1-3/8 inches in thickness, or doors in compliance with Section 716.2.2.1 with a fire protection rating of not less than 20 minutes. The door is required to be self-closing, this need is typically accomplished w/ spring loaded hinges or a door closer. The door is also required to be self-latching, and this is typically accomplished by the use of an appropriate lockset. Ducts located in the garage and ducts that penetrate walls or ceilings that separate the dwelling unit including the attic spaces from the garage are required to be constructed of sheet steel of not less than 0.019 inch (0.48 mm) in thickness and shall not have openings into the garage.

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Separated Occupancy Requirements
Open Parking Garage Beneath Groups A, I, B, M and R
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a group A, I, B, M or R building is above an Open Parking Garage the allowable height and area for the building above and the garage are determined by different sections of the code. The height and area of the garage is dictated by section 406.5. The height and area of the building above is determined by section 503, includes the height and stories of the garage and is measured from grade plane. The two buildings need to be separated by fire barriers or horizontal assemblies with fire resistance ratings per Table 508.4 for the two uses. 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire barriers or horizontal assemblies are required to separate the means of egress for the upper building from the garage.

children.body: Separated occupancies shall be individually classified in accordance with Section 302.1. Each separated space shall comply with this code based on the occupancy classification of that portion of the building. The most restrictive provisions of Chapter 9 that apply to the separate occupancies shall apply to the total nonfire-barrier-separated occupancy areas. Occupancy separations that serve to define fire area limits established in Chapter 9 for requiring a fire protection system shall also comply with Section 901.7.

diagrams.title: Commercial Kitchens: Occupancy
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Correct classification of a commercial cooking space can affect occupancy separation requirements. Sometimes kitchens are part of the dining experience, and an occupancy separation would be undesirable. However other commercial kitchen spaces can be large enough, or are meant to be a larger production space, like for an entire hospital, that the higher hazard necessitates consideration as something separate from the dining area.

children.body: In each story, the building area shall be such that the sum of the ratios of the actual building area of each separated occupancy divided by the allowable building area of each separated occupancy shall not exceed 1.

diagrams.title: Separated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Separated occupancies check the sum of the ratios of designed-to-allowable areas for each story to determine if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the sum of the ratios of each story must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California). If additional area is needed, the frontage factor based on frontage can be used to increase the values beyond the allowable area values.

Occupancy separations are required to be Fire Barriers in accordance with Table 508.4.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

diagrams.title: Building Area (Definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: According to the building code, the building area is the area included within surrounding exterior walls, or exterior walls and fire walls, exclusive of vent shafts and courts. Areas of the building not provided with surrounding walls shall be included in the building area if such areas are included within the horizontal projection of the roof or floor above.

children.body:
Each separated occupancy shall comply with the building height limitations and story limitations based on the type of construction of the building in accordance with Section 503.1.
Exception: Special provisions of Section 510 shall permit occupancies at building heights and number of stories other than provided in Section 503.1.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increase (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Although the provisions of Section 510.5 do not address sprinkler system use, the new (2021) limitations for use of NFPA 13R systems to 4 stories and 30 feet would preclude the use of NFPA 13R for a full height Type III-A building. In addition, non-sprinklered new construction for Group R occupancy is not permitted. Therefore, an NFPA 13 system would be required for this condition.

diagrams.title: Building Height on Sloping Site
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
When a site is sloping, the grade plane will likely be at a location different than the story level of the "first floor". So, simply adding the floor to floor heights and the final floor to average roof height may not provide an accurate measurement of the building height.

First, determine the location of grade plane, as a fixed location with a datum (such as elevation above sea level). Then, using the definition of "Story Above Grade Plane", determine if the story in question is either the Story Above Grade Plane, or a basement. The difference between the level of the floor of the Story Above Grade Plane will have to be either added to or subtracted from the building height, measured from the floor of the Story Above Grade Plane to determine an accurate building height measured from grade plane.

Story Above Grade Plane: Any story having its finished floor surface entirely above grade plane, or in which the finished surface of the floor next above is:

1. More than 6 feet (1829 mm) above grade plane; or
2. More than 12 feet (3658 mm) above the finished ground level at any point.

A number of code requirements are measured from grade plane. Basements are defined as not being a story above grade plane. Even though allowable building height in stories is measured from grade plane, care should be exercised in determining whether or not the story considered at grade level is indeed a "story above grade plane" which should be included in the allowable number of stories.

diagrams.title: Allow. Height & Stories: Sep. Occs.
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The height, in feet, and the number of stories of a building shall be determined based on the type of construction, occupancy classification and whether there is an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout the building. In a building containing mixed occupancies in accordance with Section 508, no individual occupancy shall exceed the height and number of story limits specified in this section for the applicable occupancies.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Horizontal Bldg. Separation (510.2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.2 provides a special condition which would allow a lesser type of construction above a Type I "podium". Sometimes there are multiple buildings over a common podium, which can be common in Group R-2 buildings.

Items that are new for 2018 codes include the allowance for vertical offsets in the horizontal assembly and a requirement for the horizontal assembly to also be Type IA construction.

diagrams.title: Separated Occupancies 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Separated occupancies check the sum of the ratios of designed-to-allowable areas for each story to determine if the building meets allowable area. The total building area must also be checked and the sum of the ratios of each story must be less than 3.0 (or 2.0 for two stories and for certain occupancy groups in California). If additional area is needed, the frontage factor based on frontage can be used to increase the values beyond the allowable area values.

Occupancy separations are required to be Fire Barriers in accordance with Table 508.4.

Further limitations on building height or area must also be checked against the Life Safety Code when applicable to a project based on the use (i.e. Medical, Business, etc).

children.displayTitle: 508.4.3 Allowable Building Height and Number of Stories
children.titleText: Allowable Building Height and Number of Stories

children.body: Individual occupancies shall be separated from adjacent occupancies in accordance with Table 508.4.

Required separations shall be fire barriers constructed in accordance with Section 707 or horizontal assemblies constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both, so as to completely separate adjacent occupancies. Mass timber elements serving as fire barriers or horizontal assemblies to separate occupancies in Type IV-B or IV-C construction shall be separated from the interior of the building with an approved thermal barrier consisting of gypsum board that is not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in thickness or a material that is tested in accordance with and meets the acceptance criteria of both the Temperature Transmission Fire Test and the Integrity Fire Test of NFPA 275.

A live/work unit shall comply with Sections 508.5 through 508.5.11.
Exception: Dwelling or sleeping units that include an office that is less than 10 percent of the area of the dwelling unit are permitted to be classified as dwelling units with accessory occupancies in accordance with Section 508.2.

diagrams.title: Live Work Unit Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Live/work units regulated under 2021-based building code Section 508.5 present a highly adaptable occupancy model, particularly well-suited to dense urban environments and multifamily developments. However, this hybrid typology comes with precise constraints that significantly influence spatial planning.

Means of egress and accessibility requrements apply based on the function of each space. Occupant loads must be calculated and documented separately for the living and working portions. Plumbing fixture count calculations also require careful attention, particularly in jurisdictions with stricter interpretations of how shared facilities may be used. If a tenant brings in external workers or clients—even occasionally—it may shift the classification of the work zone in ways that trigger more demanding requirements for fixtures, structural design, or fire protection. Uses such as light fabrication, artist studios, or boutique production can blur the line between permitted commercial activities and those prohibited under Group H or S occupancies, such as those involving hazardous materials or heavy storage. It is essential to engage the Authority Having Jurisdiction (AHJ) early to determine how they define and enforce these distinctions in mixed-use contexts.

Egress requirements must be carefully considered before simply choosing something like a spiral stair or residential style stairway. Ventilation requirements under the Mechanical Code must be applied according to the function of each space, which could complicate HVAC zoning and system layouts. Similarly, fire alarm and sprinkler designs must account for both residential and commercial activities within a single unit envelope. These complexities demand a multidisciplinary approach to design coordination—where architecture, mechanical systems, code compliance, and occupancy planning are considered together from the earliest project stages.

children.body:
The following shall apply to live/work areas:
  1. The live/work unit is permitted to be not greater than 3,000 square feet (279 m2) in area.
  2. The nonresidential area is permitted to be not more than 50 percent of the area of each live/work unit.
  3. The nonresidential area function shall be limited to the first or main floor only of the live/work unit.
  4. Not more than five nonresidential workers or employees are allowed to occupy the nonresidential area at any one time.

Live/work units shall be classified as a Group R-2 occupancy. Separation requirements found in Sections 420 and 508 shall not apply within the live/work unit where the live/work unit is in compliance with Section 508.5. Nonresidential uses that would otherwise be classified as either a Group H or S occupancy shall not be permitted in a live/work unit.
Exception: Storage shall be permitted in the live/work unit provided that the aggregate area of storage in the nonresidential portion of the live/work unit shall be limited to 10 percent of the space dedicated to nonresidential activities.
Except as modified by this section, the means of egress components for a live/work unit shall be designed in accordance with Chapter 10 for the function served.
The egress capacity for each element of the live/work unit shall be based on the occupant load for the function served in accordance with Table 1004.5.
Spiral stairways that conform to the requirements of Section 1011.10 shall be permitted.
Floor openings between floor levels of a live/work unit are permitted without enclosure.
The live/work unit shall be provided with a monitored fire alarm system where required by Section 907.2.9 and an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.2.8.
Floors within a live/work unit shall be designed for the live loads in Table 1607.1, based on the function within the space.
Accessibility shall be designed in accordance with Chapter 11 for the function served.
The applicable ventilation requirements of the International Mechanical Code shall apply to each area within the live/work unit for the function within that space.

The nonresidential area of the live/work unit shall be provided with minimum plumbing facilities as specified by Chapter 29, based on the function of the nonresidential area. Where the nonresidential area of the live/work unit is required to be accessible by Section 1108.6.2.1, the plumbing fixtures specified by Chapter 29 shall be accessible.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses: Occupancy Classification and Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental use areas on any given level of a building may not occupy more than 10% of the building area of that level. Incidental use areas take on the occupancy classification of the occupancy which the incidental use area is located within.

children.body:
Incidental uses located within single occupancy or mixed occupancy buildings shall comply with the provisions of this section. Incidental uses are ancillary functions associated with a given occupancy that generally pose a greater level of risk to that occupancy and are limited to those uses specified in Table 509.1.
Exception: Incidental uses within and serving a dwelling unit are not required to comply with this section.

diagrams.title: Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

diagrams.title: Incidental Use Areas
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental uses similar to accessory uses take on the occupancy of the primary use for which they are provided for. Allowed incidental uses are listed in Table 509. An incidental use's area is limited to 10% of the floor in which it is located. Because incidental uses generally pose a greater level of risk, separation of the incidental use from the remainder of the building or additional protection of the incidental use is required. The level of required separation or protection depends on the actual incidental use and is listed in Table 509. Note that Incidental uses within and serving a dwelling unit are not required to comply with section 509 separation or protection measures.

diagrams.title: Appliance Access
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A work space at least 30" wide by 30" deep must be provided immediately in front of the appliance's controls. Access to appliances needs to allow for the appliance to be inspected, operated, serviced and/or replaced without the removal of or disabling the function of any of the following:
  • Fire-resistance rated assembly
  • Permanent Construction such as walls, floors and ceilings
  • Other appliances
  • Venting systems, Ducts or Pipes not connected to the appliance

diagrams.title: Multiple Occupancy Building: Non-Separated Occupancy Requirements
Nursing Home Areas Open to Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 nursing home areas, shared living, meeting, or therapeutic spaces may open directly to corridors if specific safety requirements are met. These include constructing walls and ceilings to corridor standards, ensuring the spaces are not used for sleeping, treatment, hazardous, or incidental uses, and providing automatic fire detection systems. Additionally, corridors in the same smoke compartment must have fire detection or the compartment must have quick response sprinklers, and the layout must maintain clear access to required exits.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses - Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental uses are required to be separated per Table 509. Where a horizontal separation is required the code requires that the separation assembly is supported by construction of equal or greater fire-resistance protection as the assembly being supported. Where the horizontal assembly is separating an incidental use in a Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction and is not required to exceed a 1 hour fire-resistance rating the construction supporting the horizontal assembly is not required to be protected.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses: Laundry Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Laundry rooms over 100 sf in area are considered an incidental use. Per Table 509.1 they must be separated from the rest of the building by 1 hour fire rated construction and be protected by an automatic sprinkler system. Laundry rooms that are part of and serve and individual dwelling unit do not require any separation or protection.

children.body: Incidental uses shall not be individually classified in accordance with Section 302.1. Incidental uses shall be included in the building occupancies within which they are located.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses: Occupancy Classification and Area
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental use areas on any given level of a building may not occupy more than 10% of the building area of that level. Incidental use areas take on the occupancy classification of the occupancy which the incidental use area is located within.

children.body: Incidental uses shall not occupy more than 10 percent of the building area of the story in which they are located.

The incidental uses specified in Table 509.1 shall be separated from the remainder of the building or equipped with an automatic sprinkler system, or both, in accordance with the provisions of that table.

diagrams.title: Corridor doors in Group I-2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In a group I-2 occupancy, doors in corridor walls not required to provide fire separation from incidental uses, vertical openings (shafts), or exits are not required to have a fire protection rating or to have self/automatic-closing devices. They must, however, provide an effective smoke barrier and be equipped with positive latching lockset (roller latches not permitted). Where the corridor wall is required to be rated the door openings are required to be protected in accordance with Table 716.1(2).

children.body: Where Table 509.1 specifies a fire-resistance-rated separation, the incidental uses shall be separated from the remainder of the building by a fire barrier constructed in accordance with Section 707 or a horizontal assembly constructed in accordance with Section 711, or both. Construction supporting 1-hour fire barriers or horizontal assemblies used for incidental use separations in buildings of Type IIB, IIIB and VB construction is not required to be fire-resistance rated unless required by other sections of this code.

Where Table 509.1 specifies a fire-resistance-rated separation, mass timber elements serving as fire barriers or horizontal assemblies in Type IV-B or IV-C construction shall be separated from the interior of the incidental use with an approved thermal barrier consisting of gypsum board that is not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) in thickness or a material that is tested in accordance with and meets the acceptance criteria of both the Temperature Transmission Fire Test and the Integrity Fire Test of NFPA 275.

Where Table 509.1 permits an automatic sprinkler system without a fire barrier, the incidental uses shall be separated from the remainder of the building by construction capable of resisting the passage of smoke. The walls shall extend from the top of the foundation or floor assembly below to the underside of the ceiling that is a component of a fire-resistance-rated floor assembly or roof assembly above or to the underside of the floor or roof sheathing, deck or slab above. Doors shall be self- or automatic-closing upon detection of smoke in accordance with Section 716.2.6.6. Doors shall not have air transfer openings and shall not be undercut in excess of the clearance permitted in accordance with NFPA 80. Walls surrounding the incidental use shall not have air transfer openings unless provided with smoke dampers in accordance with Section 710.8.

diagrams.title: Fire & Smoke: Walls vs. Barriers vs. Partitions
Door Fire Ratings in Protective Wall Assemblies
Required Fire Ratings for Protective Wall Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The various wall assemblies outlined in the table represent a hierarchy of fire and smoke protection strategies, each serving a specific code-defined function. Fire walls, governed by BC 706, provide the highest level of protection. They are structurally independent and typically rated for 3 to 4 hours, intended to subdivide buildings into separate code-compliant structures. This makes them essential in controlling fire area limits and enabling larger building footprints.

Fire barriers under BC 707 are slightly less stringent but highly versatile. With ratings ranging from 1 to 4 hours, they are commonly used to separate occupancies, vertical shafts, and hazardous areas. Unlike fire walls, they are not required to be structurally independent, making them more adaptable in multi-story construction while still offering robust fire containment.

Moving further down the spectrum, fire partitions (BC 708) and smoke barriers (BC 709) typically carry 1-hour ratings. Fire partitions are used in less critical separations such as between dwelling units or corridors, while smoke barriers are designed to limit the spread of smoke across smoke compartments, particularly in healthcare occupancies. Smoke partitions (BC 710), by contrast, have no fire rating but are required to resist smoke passage, making them suitable for spaces like corridors in sprinklered buildings.

Lastly, protection for sprinklered incidental uses (BC 509.4.2) can sometimes forgo a fire-resistance rating altogether if automatic sprinklers are provided. This reflects a performance-based allowance in the code that balances passive and active fire protection measures. Understanding the distinctions among these wall types is key for aligning life safety objectives with code compliance and constructibility.

children.body: Where an automatic sprinkler system is provided in accordance with Table 509.1, only the space occupied by the incidental use need be equipped with such a system.

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses: Laundry Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Laundry rooms over 100 sf in area are considered an incidental use. Per Table 509.1 they must be separated from the rest of the building by 1 hour fire rated construction and be protected by an automatic sprinkler system. Laundry rooms that are part of and serve and individual dwelling unit do not require any separation or protection.

diagrams.title: Open Parking Garage Beneath Groups A, I, B, M and R
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a group A, I, B, M or R building is above an Open Parking Garage the allowable height and area for the building above and the garage are determined by different sections of the code. The height and area of the garage is dictated by section 406.5. The height and area of the building above is determined by section 503, includes the height and stories of the garage and is measured from grade plane. The two buildings need to be separated by fire barriers or horizontal assemblies with fire resistance ratings per Table 508.4 for the two uses. 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire barriers or horizontal assemblies are required to separate the means of egress for the upper building from the garage.

diagrams.title: Group S-2 Enclosed Parking Garage With Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
A Group S-2 enclosed parking garage with no more than one story above grade plane, located beneath a Group S-2 open parking garage, is considered a separate building for construction type purposes if the following conditions are met:
  • The sum of area actual area to allowable area ratios of both occupancies must not exceed 1;
  • The enclosed garage is of type I or II construction and has equal or greater fire resistance than required for the open parking garage;
  • The open garage complies with height and tier limits in Table 406.5.4;
  • The floor assembly separating the two types of garages must meet the enclosed garage's fire protection requirements;
  • Openings other than exit openings between the two garage types are not required to be protected;
  • And the enclosed garage must be used solely for private vehicle parking or storage.
An accessory use area up to 1000 sf that may contain an office, waiting room, and toilet room is allowed in the enclosed garage. The enclosed garage may also contain a mechanical room that serves the building.

diagrams.title: Vertical Offsets in Podium Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a vertical offset is part of a horizontal assembly utilized to establish separate buildings the offset is required to be constructed as a 3 hour minimum fire-resistance rated fire barrier per Section 707. Structural elements that support the fire-barrier need protection equal to or greater than the fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier being supported.

diagrams.title: Vertical Offsets in Podium Horizontal Assemblies - Cross Section
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where a vertical offset is part of a horizontal assembly utilized to establish separate buildings the offset is required to be constructed as a 3 hour minimum fire-resistance rated fire barrier per Section 707. Structural elements that support the fire-barrier need protection equal to or greater than the fire-resistance rating of the fire barrier being supported.

diagrams.title: Group B or M Bldgs w/ Group S-2 Open Parking Garage Above
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The code provides a special provision to allow for vehicle parking to be placed above a place of business or retail. For the purpose of determining the type of construction, an S-2 open parking structure may be considered separately from a group B or M occupancy building below when all of the following conditions are met:
  1. A horizontal assembly of not less than 2 hours fire-resistance separates the two buildings
  2. The occupancy of the building below is limited to group B and M
  3. The occupancy of the building above is limited to a Group S-2 open parking garage
  4. The building below the horizontal assembly is of type IA construction. Exception: Where the building below is limited to 1 story in height the construction type for the lower building may be type IB or II but not less than the construction type required by the S-2 open parking garage above.
  5. The lower building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 503 (table 504).
  6. The upper building complies with the height and area limits set forth in Section 406.5. The height, in both feet and stories, shall be measured from grade plane and include the building below.
  7. Exits serving the garage discharge at grade with direct access to a street or public way and are separated from the building below by 2-hour fire barriers, 2-hour horizontal assemblies or both.

children.body: The provisions in Sections 510.2 through 510.9 shall permit the use of special conditions that are exempt from, or modify, the specific requirements of this chapter regarding the allowable building heights and areas of buildings based on the occupancy classification and type of construction, provided the special condition complies with the provisions specified in this section for such condition and other applicable requirements of this code. The provisions of Sections 510.2 through 510.8 are to be considered independent and separate from each other.

diagrams.title: Building Height Measurements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Building Height is measured vertically from grade plane to the average height of the highest roof surface. If podium construction or other conditions are used, the provisions of BC Section 510 would apply as applicable. The building code definition of building height is often different from those used in planning / zoning ordinances. In addition, the current definition is different than a previous version in the building code that defined building height for various types of roof structures. Under the current definition, the building height is not measured to the top of the parapet coping.

children.body:
A building shall be considered as separate and distinct buildings for the purpose of determining area limitations, continuity of fire walls, limitation of number of stories and type of construction where the following conditions are met:
  1. The buildings are separated with a horizontal assembly having a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours. Where vertical offsets are provided as part of a horizontal assembly, the vertical offset and the structure supporting the vertical offset shall have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 3 hours.
  2. The building below, including the horizontal assembly, is of Type IA construction.
  3. Shaft, stairway, ramp and escalator enclosures through the horizontal assembly shall have not less than a 2-hour fire-resistance rating with opening protectives in accordance with Section 716.
    Exception: Where the enclosure walls below the horizontal assembly have not less than a 3-hour fire-resistance rating with opening protectives in accordance with Section 716, the enclosure walls extending above the horizontal assembly shall be permitted to have a 1-hour fire-resistance rating, provided that the following conditions are met:
    1. The building above the horizontal assembly is not required to be of Type I construction.
    2. The enclosure connects fewer than four stories.
    3. The enclosure opening protectives above the horizontal assembly have a fire protection rating of not less than 1 hour.
  4. Interior exit stairways located within the Type IA building are permitted to be of combustible materials where the following requirements are met:
    1. The building above the Type IA building is of Type III, IV, or V construction.
    2. The stairway located in the Type IA building is enclosed by 3-hour fire-resistance-rated construction with opening protectives in accordance with Section 716.
  5. The building or buildings above the horizontal assembly shall be permitted to have multiple Group A occupancy uses, each with an occupant load of less than 300, or Group B, M, R or S occupancies.
  6. The building below the horizontal assembly shall be protected throughout by an approved automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, and shall be permitted to be any occupancy allowed by this code except Group H.
  7. The maximum building height in feet (mm) shall not exceed the limits set forth in Section 504.3 for the building having the smaller allowable height as measured from the grade plane.

diagrams.title: Attic Fire Protection - Condition 3 & 4 (NFPA 13R)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When using NFPA 13R sprinklers, attic protection is required for specific podium construction and Group R-4, Condition 2 situations.

diagrams.title: NFPA 13R System Scoping (2021)
